channel.title: Revision Techniques
channel.description: Well i have exams and i know revising can be hard so here are some(wierd) but other otherwise plausible techniques. Right the brain remembers stabs of emotion and/or pain as they stand out vividly in a mind. So to remember something say it out loud to yourself between intermittent punches from a friend. The brain relates that word with the pain from the punches and it will stick for longer. Same as if you got aroused every time you said this fact your brain will remember, but if you were to do it when you were hungry the fact would be lost because hunger isnt intermittent it is constant its something that does work and the same with shouting if someone shouts something at you in anger you will remember it. They are strange but they work.

I’ve seen a play called blood brothers, probably the same story as the play. I saw it when me and Susie were going to the same school, before we were together, and now we are going to see it again in a few weeks ^.^
[/quote]
I had to go to the phoeniz in london to wtach for drama abd then we acted it for our drama coursework[/quote]

Lol, so did I man. That shitty theater in a side street near Waterloo. Let me know how the exam goes tomorrow man. Good luck.

item.title: Revision Techniques
item.dc:creator: @I_Br3ndan_I I Br3ndan I
item.description:
@I_Br3ndan_I wrote:

No magma, that’s more craft and design, or just craft. Packaging in graphics is different. You’re making a package for something like a toy, perfume, anything relatively small really. They have to be in complex shapes in order for you to get a 1 (1 is the best you can achieve in standard grade at my school. For intermediate 1 and 2, higher and advanced higher, an A would be the best. It’s the same for GCSEs?), such as hexagonal prisms, triangular prisms, cones, cylinders, etc. Simple shapes must have a cut in them to achieve a good grade.

I made a cut hexagonal prism for pencils (Cut in 1/2). Dono my grade for it. Teacher said everybody pretty much got a good one.

Read full topic

i don’t mean jsut a box you have gotta design the packaging and stuff like that then you have to make it i should have explained myself better

item.title: Revision Techniques
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“I Br3ndan I, post:16, topic:205851”]They might have it… I’m not trying to call you stupid or anything, but it’s proper name is “Graphic Communication”. I know you’d know if it were in your school since we’re calling it graphics, but it’s just to give you a better idea of the proper name incase it’s called something else at your school. I’m a little surprised it isn’t available to you.

Whoa, omg, big sentence coming up. Brace yourself.

Here’s an example of a drawing in graphics people our age would draw (I’m 15, so I’m doing standard grades, those are the Scottish equivalent of GCSEs), it’s a cone, shown from different views (Sides are elevations, front and back are end elevations, top is plan, if shown, the surface development is the shape ‘folded out’, this shows us how the different faces of the shape, where and how they’re joined together, and finally, if shown, the true shape, which is projected from the elevation of a drawing to show the true face of a shape that is cut):[/quote]
We have Graphics at our school but its a bit different you have to design boxes for products and such things like that its kinda complicated i didn’t take because basically i suck at it

Read full topic

item.title: Revision Techniques
item.dc:creator: @I_Br3ndan_I I Br3ndan I
item.description:
@I_Br3ndan_I wrote:

They might have it… I’m not trying to call you stupid or anything, but it’s proper name is “Graphic Communication”. I know you’d know if it were in your school since we’re calling it graphics, but it’s just to give you a better idea of the proper name incase it’s called something else at your school. I’m a little surprised it isn’t available to you.

Whoa, omg, big sentence coming up. Brace yourself.

Here’s an example of a drawing in graphics people our age would draw (I’m 15, so I’m doing standard grades, those are the Scottish equivalent of GCSEs), it’s a cone, shown from different views (Sides are elevations, front and back are end elevations, top is plan, if shown, the surface development is the shape ‘folded out’, this shows us how the different faces of the shape, where and how they’re joined together, and finally, if shown, the true shape, which is projected from the elevation of a drawing to show the true face of a shape that is cut):

14251_62_1.jpg315×551

Sorry, that isn’t a very good example. You get the gist of it though. It’s very, very complicated. Once you’ve understood it though, you completely dominate the drawing and can produce them much more efficiently.

Read full topic

item.title: Revision Techniques
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

[quote=“I Br3ndan I, post:14, topic:205851”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=271579.msg2229638#msg2229638 date=1211070471]
Says the graphics master
[/quote]

It’s not about drawing freehand or anything. You have to draw properly. Think of it as architecture. People our age only work on small shapes though, not buildings or anything. It’s very complex and technical, not like expressing yourself on paper with a drawing material or using PS to make something.[/quote]
Its like architecture you say? Damn I wish my school had Graphics; I’d quite like to have an art influence that was sort of towards architecture. All of my subjects are academic actually and I don’t have any art subjects.

Read full topic

item.title: Revision Techniques
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:6, topic:205851”]I get onto study leave tomorrow. In my experience I perform better in exams if I don’t revise. I don’t know if I’m lucky or cocky or whether it actually works.

I will only revise if I feel that I don’t actually know anything, I’m planning to revise for biology and perhaps a few other subjects. Otherwise I just chill out and not get myself worked up and just take every day as it comes.

Good luck with your GCSE’s guise. Can’t wait till they are all over and we can all start some summer lovin’.[/quote]
Amen to that

Read full topic
